title: Lev: 'Trojan War' takes USC fans back to happier times
text:
LOS ANGELES – Frustrated USC fans seeking a return to the glory days can take a traffic-free trip down Memory Lane on Tuesday night.
The latest “30 for 30” documentary, “Trojan War,” premieres at 6 p.m. on ESPN. It will stir many emotions within the Trojan Family.
The film, directed by Aaron Rahsaan Thomas, depicts the rise and “fall” of the USC football program under Pete Carroll in the 2000s. About two-thirds of it focuses on the good times – Carson Palmer winning the Heisman Trophy, USC winning back-to-back national championships, Reggie Bush making the magic happen against Fresno State. The film praises Carroll for recognizing the connection between USC and Hollywood and wisely using that to his advantage.
The film posits the 2006 Rose Bowl national championship loss to Texas as a pivot point. Narrator Michael B. Jordan describes it as “the beginning of the end of one of college football’s greatest empires.” The footage shown of that game, as well as the others, will give you goose bumps.
Whether it actually was the beginning of the end is a matter of debate. “Trojan War” neglects to mention that USC went 34-5 over the next three seasons, winning three consecutive Rose Bowls. Even in the dark days of the Lane Kiffin-Steve Sarkisian era, the Trojans twice won 10 games and never won fewer than seven.
Obviously, the football program hasn’t reached its previous heights, which have been described as unprecedented for a reason. Attempts to recapture that time have proved futile, and it’s among many reasons USC likely will venture away from the Carroll coaching tree to replace the fired Sarkisian.
“Trojan War” focuses on three main figures besides Carroll: quarterback Matt Leinart, running back LenDale White and Bush – the latter for obvious reasons. The film explains what went down with Bush and how it led to USC receiving NCAA sanctions that were practically unprecedented. It won’t satisfy Trojans fans who are still bitter about how unfair those sanctions were.
After a recent screening at an L.A. theater, producer Mario Diaz said the film at one time included a six- to seven-minute segment on the corruption of the NCAA – but that it had to be cut for editing reasons. (The filmmakers had several hundred hours of footage that had to be condensed into 77 minutes). The segment is expected to be included among the DVD extras. Frankly, it’s a big enough topic for its own “30 for 30” film. “Trojan War II,” perhaps?
Carroll, Leinart and White are among many people with direct and indirect USC ties who sat down to be interviewed. They include Snoop Dogg (who’s spectacularly funny), Texas grad Lance Armstrong (who’s referred to as “former cyclist” and aptly says “I know what it’s like” in reference to Bush being banished from USC) and agent-turned-author Josh Luchs (who wasn’t part of the USC scene and doesn’t belong in the film).
Bush declined to participate. Keyshawn Johnson, one of the film’s executive producers, said he contacted Bush about 40 times over the past 21/2 years, “but at the end of the day, it just wasn’t something he was comfortable doing.”
There are moments in “Trojan War” that might make you squirm. The ones that make you want to jump out of your seat far outnumber them.
THE SPORTS GUY’S GUYS 
It appears Bill Simmons is getting the band back together.
Four members of the editorial staff at ESPN’s Grantland.com announced Monday that they would be leaving the website to join Simmons to work on an unnamed project.
We know Simmons will have a show on HBO starting next year. He also has resumed podcasting. (In just two weeks time, “The Bill Simmons Podcast” has cracked iTunes’ top 10 .) Could a new, Grantland-esque website be next?
“I still have to figure out where I’m going to write and how much I’m going to write,” Simmons said at the recent Vanity Fair New Establishment Summit .
The future of Grantland, which Simmons founded, is also uncertain. Another prominent editor, Dan Fierman, has left to oversee MTV News.
Since resurfacing, Simmons has complained about a lack of corporate support for Grantland and his popular “BS Report” podcast. He already has secured several sponsors for his new podcast.
REMOTE PATROL 
The changes continue at Fox Sports 1, which canceled “America’s Pregame” earlier this month, causing many people to lose their jobs. FS1 currently is airing a Colin Cowherd best-of show at 2 p.m. but plans to remake its afternoon slate into a “more opinion-focused programming block,” according to John Ourand of SportsBusiness Daily . Given Fox Sports exec Jamie Horowitz’s track record on ESPN, you can surmise where this is headed. …
You couldn’t ask for better markets in the NLDS, and TV viewership reflects as much. Through Saturday, TBS’ MLB postseason telecasts were averaging 5.4 million viewers – the network’s highest average on record through two Division Series games and up 39 percent over last year. … Fox reported a 16 percent increase in average viewers for regular-season MLB game telecasts over 2014. MLB games on FS1 were up 22 percent. …
Longtime L.A. Times sports columnist and ESPN “Around the Horn” panelist Bill Plaschke is Jeanne Zelasko’s new co-host from 6-9 a.m. on The Beast 980, which already has undergone significant changes since launching in September 2014. More are coming in the 12-3 p.m. and 3-7 time slots. Current 12-3 host Fred Roggin is expected to remain part of the afternoon lineup. … ESPN Radio’s “Russillo & Kanell” (10 a.m.-1 p.m. PT weekdays) is now being simulcast in full on ESPNEWS. …
The Pac-12 last week announced a multiyear agreement with Beijing-based streaming service Letv to stream regular-season football games. So, once again, if you’re a DirecTV subscriber seeking Pac-12 Networks content, you’re better off living in China than L.A. … If you do have Pac-12 Networks, they’re providing three hours of coverage of Pac-12 Men’s Basketball Media Day on Thursday. Coverage starts at 10 a.m. and features interviews with all 12 league coaches and several players. …
Through its first four weeks, ratings for “Thursday Night Football” on CBS and NFL Network were up 16 percent over last year. … The NFL and SiriusXM announced a six-year extension. The satellite radio service will continue to provide live broadcasts of every NFL game as well as a channel devoted entirely to NFL programming. … The NFL also announced a partnership with TuneIn, making all play-by-play broadcasts available to TuneIn Premium subscribers. The TuneIn app is free. Premium costs $7.99 per month. … Cole Wright has been named host of NFL Network’s “NFL HQ,” which airs daily at 5 and 7 a.m. …
The panelists on the latest episode of “Open Court” On NBA TV will name all-decade teams for the past five decades (1960s-2000s). The episode debuts at 6:30 p.m. Tuesday. … Campus Insiders soon will become part of Sling TV’s $5-a-month “Sports Extra” package. The basic Sling TV service – whose 20-plus channels include ESPN, ESPN2, TBS and TNT – costs $20 per month. … Viewership of NHL games on NBC Sports Group rose 79 percent over the first 10 years it had the package (559,000 in 2005-06; 1.002 million in ’14-15).
